body: you should probably prefix your elements with something like `alertify` since it wouldnt be unreasonable for somebody to already have an `aText` id :)

body: Indentation
spaces before and after the function brackets... e.g. function () {
spaces before and after ===
since this "logElement.removeChild(elem)" is called twice... maybe an inner function in the close method would be useful for DRY.  thoughts?

That's your call. Both instances of that are very close to each other (so presumably hard to miss if updating one) and wrapping it in a function might even take more space/size than just leaving it. But if adhering to DRY is important, it wouldn't be a crazy thing to change.

I'm good with the way it is. As you said, they're close and it's a one liner. Not an issue to update both if ever a change is needed. 

Sent from my iPhone

maybe throw an error catching statement here

``` js
if (wait && typeof wait !== "number") throw new Error("wait parameter must be a number");
```

I was thinking a 1 line addition, don't like how it adds 10 lines. Maybe a silent failure is better (as you originally had). I do like the testing of the wait number though. I would comment the unary plus since it's not obvious what it does (for everyone)

``` js
// +wait -> Unary Plus,  evaluates operand and attempts to converts it into a number
var timer = (wait && !isNaN(wait)) ? +wait : delay
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -104,11 +110,13 @@
 				var btnReset  = $("alertify-resetFocus"),
 				    btnOK     = $("alertify-ok")     || undefined,
 				    btnCancel = $("alertify-cancel") || undefined,
+				    btnFocus  = (_alertify.buttonFocus == 'cancel') ? btnCancel : ((_alertify.buttonFocus == 'none') ? null : btnOK),
body:
=== instead of ==
" instead of '

The only issue I have is with null. If focus isn't set to either button, than a keyboard user will have to tab through the entire page to reach the button of the DOM and enter the dialog element before being able to click a button. (or resort to using the mouse)

Could add another empty `<a>` in the dialog and assign focus to it? Seems a bit hacky...

This isn't needed. The `reset` function is only to keep the focus inside the dialog. So tabbing through should ignore the `buttonFocus` property and simply set the focus on the first element available. `input`, `cancel` and `ok` respectively.

space between `if` and `(`

and same issue as above with null. focus remains in the middle of the page and users need to tab through all the DOM to get to the dialog.

body:
If the desire is to have nothing focused, then the desire is to use the mouse anyway - the idea being to slow the user down and have them really consider what the dialog is saying.

I'm unable to tab the buttons into focus anyway - either when using my updated code or the original.
if there are no `{ }` keep on 1 line...  and also no spaces between `=` on class attribute
one last nitpick... space between `if (`

i have thought about that option, but what i found is that the browser will show the focus border around the body and it does seem kinda strange/annoying since the user didn't trigger the alertrify from the body (i know that you can hide this w/ css, but it seems unnecessary).  is it necessary to always reset the focus back to some element after the dialog is closed?

> is it necessary to always reset the focus back to some element after the dialog is closed?

Nope. I was just curious!
